page.title: 10FARMING
page.content: {TYPE OF FARMING AND FARMLAND There are many farms in this agricultural area with its rich, medium to heavy loam soil. About two-thirds is arable, mostly corn and oil seed rape but also wheat, barley and vegetables like potatoes. The rest is pasture land for grazing sheep and cattle and grass crops for winter feed. The land has a natural drainage due to the ridge and furrow system to take away excess water into brooks, but some fields still get very wet at times.It is mostly owned by Merton College, Oxford, whose founder, Walter de Merton, purchased it in the 13th century. Some local tenant farmers still prefer the old clay drainage pipes to the modern, cheaper, plastic ones because they last longer.
